DIV2.HEAD: BISHOPS OF DURHAM, FROM THE FIRST.
DIV2.P: 634 Aidane—created and sent to preach the gospel to the Northumbrians.
652 Finane—he baptized Sigebert, King of the East Saxons.
662 Coleman—who resigned his bishoprick on a controversy which arose about the celebration of Easter.

666 Tuda was ordained, and the same year died of the plague, which then raged in Northum∣berland. The see was governed 14 years by Eata, then Abbot of Holy Island, after when time he was made Bishop of the same see, and continued so four years.

685 St. Cuthbert—he was consecrated at York by Theodore, then Archbishop, King Egfrid and seven bishops being present at the consecration, which was upon Easter-day. Upon the de∣cease of St. Cuthbert, the see was governed by
687 Wilfrid, Archbishop of York.
688 Eadbert—in this Bishop's time the corpse of St. Cuthbert were removed after lying 11 years, on opening the sepulchre, they found the body sound, sweet, and flexible, as it were a man sleeping.
Eadfrid succeeded and continued 24 years, and to him succeeded
Ethelwolf—who was bishop 16 years. After him

Cynwolfe was bishop 14 years, and resigned by reason of old age. He committed the charge of his bishoprick to one Higbald, who
governed it almost 4 years; and at his death
Higbald was made bishop, and held the see 22 years. After him
Egbert—was made bishop, and continued 18 years, when
Heathrude succeeded, and was bishop 9 years. In his stead
Egrade was elected, and was bishop 16 years. After him succeeded
Eadbert, who was bishop 8 years. Then

854 Eardulph—At this time certain Danes and Pa∣gans of divers other nations invaded and de∣stroyed this nation in many parts; and Hal∣dane, king of the Danes, with a great army, arrived in Tinmouth haven, with intent to destroy the county of Northumberland, plun∣dered and destroyed great part of the superb Abbey, at Tinmouth; when the bishop and clergy took the corpse of St. Cuthbert, and fled with it from place to place, without any certain rest, for almost the space of 7 years, to avoid the merciless infidels. The said Ear∣dulph was bishop of Chester above 18 years.
Cutheard was made bishop in his room, who purchased many lands and possessions, and gave them to the Church of St. Cuthbert.
After his death Trelede succeeded in the see, and continued 14 years and three months.
Wigrede was elected, after his decease, and continued 17 years. After whom
Whrede was Bishop 3 years. Then one
Sexhelme was ordained Bishop, but continued not above six months. After him succeeded
Elflige, who was bishop 22 years.

990 Aldune was consecrated Bishop, and continued at helter upwards of 5 years, and in whose
time the corpse of St. Cuthbert was removed to Durham, for their future repository.
1020 Edmund, a secular priest, succeeded, in whose time Durham was besieged by Duncan, King of Scots. After Edmund's death.

1042 Eadred, a secular priest, and assistant to the former in the government of his diocese, usurped the see, and on the first entering the church as Bishop, was suddenly deprived of the use of his limbs, and lay bed-ridden till the tenth month of his usurpation, when he died.

Egelrick succeeded, he pulled down the church of Chester, which was built with wood, and erected a new one of stone; in digging the foundation he found a great quantity of trea∣sure, which he sent to the monastery of Peter∣borough, and, having resigned the see to his brother,
Egelwin, followed it thither. The see con∣tinued vacant one year, when

1072 Walcher, a secular priest, and of noble paren∣tage, was consecrated at Winchester, and died in the ninth year of his consecration: he bought the government of Northumberland, but oppressed the people with so much extor∣tion, that he became odious to them, and on his going to Gateshead, to settle controversies between certain Northumbrians and his ser∣vants, the people rose upon him there and murdered him, with sundry of his clergy and all his attendants, about 100 in number,
1080 and burnt down the church, where they had fled for sanctuary. The see was vacant 6 months and 10 days, when

1081 William de Carileph, a Monk, was consecra∣ted Bishop, who added several lands for the
emolument of the Monks. This Bishop fell under the displeasure of King William Rufus, who seized the bishoprick and kept it in his own hands for 3 years; but was afterwards, for certain good services, restored to his for∣mer dignity and place. This prelate began to build the present Abbey or Cathedral Church at Durham, but died nine years before it was finished. After a vacancy in the see for 3 years

199 Randulph Flamberd, of the secular order, and chaplain to the king, was consecrated Bishop; he was in such high favour with the king that he made him his treasurer and chancel∣lor; but in the reign of Henry I. he was, for a certain time, banished the realm; in the mean time, the king seized upon the see, and dismembered it of Hexham and Carlisle, which from the days of St. Cuthbert, had been an∣nexed to it; but, for certain political reasons, was again seated in the chair. The see was vacant 5 years, after which

1133 Galfrid Rufus, Lord Chancellor to Henry T. was consecrated. He built the castle at Nor∣thallerton, and died 1140. The see was again vacant 3 years, through the usurpation of William Comyn, a Scottish clerk, but after that time
1143 William de sa Barbara was elected Bishop. He died Nov, 1152, and was succeeded by

1153 Hugh de Pudsey, a secular priest, of noble ex∣traction, Lord Chief Justice, &c. He purchased of the king, the earldom of Northumberland, and the manor of Sadburgh, which formerly belonged to the church, for eleven thousand
pounds; he died March 3, 1195. After a vacancy in the see of almost two years,
1197 Philip, of Poictiers, was elected Bishop, and, by a licence of King John, set up a mint at
1207 Durham, and began to coin money. After his decease, the see was vacant 5 years, 10 Months, and 24 days, when
1214 Richard de Marisco, chancellor to King John, was consecrated; he was a prodigal prelate, and left the see very much in debt. He died at Peterborough, and to him succeeded
1226 Richard, surnamed the Poor, who made him∣self honourable, by clearing his predecessor's debts; he died April 15, 1237. His death made way for
1237 Nicholas Farnham, who was physician to the Queen. He founded the hospital of St. Ed∣mund, in Gateshead, and resigned his bisho∣prick 8 years before his death. He died 1257, and was succeeded by
1259 Walter de Kirkham, a monk, who built a third part of the bridge over the river Tyne, the former one, being of wood, was burnt down. He died 1260, and
1262 Robert Stichel was elected; he was Bishop 14 years. After his death
Robert of the Isle obtained the see; he was Bishop 9 years, and died June 7, 1283. He was succeeded by
Anthony Beck, who had the title of patriarch of Jerusalem, by the Pope; he died March 3, 1313, and was Bishop 28 years.
1313 Richard Kellow, a monk at Durham, was his successor, in whose time the city of Durham was burnt down by the Scots; his death made way for
1317 Lewis Beaumont, descendant of the royal fa∣mily of France, but was so illiterate that he could not read the bill of his own conse∣cration; he died Sept. 28, 1333.
1333 Thomas de Bury was his successor; he was made Lord Chancellor of England, and died April, 1345.
Thomas Hatfield, secretary of state to Edward III. and lord of the privy seal, was next pro∣moted to this see. He died 1381. In this Bishop's time the famous battle of Durham
1346 was fought, when David Bruce, King of Scotland, with several of his nobles, were made prisoners. The next was
1382 John Fordham, who held the see 7 years, and was then deprived of his bishoprick, when
1389 Walter Skirlaw was next translated hither, from Bath; he built a great part of the steeple and lanthorn of York minster.
1404 Thomas Langley, chancellor of England, suc∣ceeded him; he built the gaol and gaol∣gates at Durham, and died Nov. 20, 1437, and
Robert Nevil was translated to the see; he built the Exchequer, upon the Palace-green, and died 1457.
1457 Laurence Booth succeeded him, and was Lord Chancellor of England. He was translated to York, on which
1473 William Dudley was chosen, who held the bishoprick 6 years, and died in 1483. Then the see was given to the learned
John Sherwood, who died 1494. After his death
Richard Fox was removed from Bath and Wells to the see, and was succeeded by
1502 William Sinows, who died 1505. After a vacancy of 2 years
1507 Christopher Bambridge obtained the see, and after one year was translated to York; and, a short time after, made a cardinal, which made way for
1508 Thomas Ruthall, who died of grief at London, 1522. After his death
Thomas Wolsey, cardinal of Rome, archbishop of York, and chancellor of England, seized the bishoprick into his own hands, and hold it seven years; he died Nov. 27, 1530.

Cuthbert Tunstal, bishop of London, was his successor. He was committed to the custody of the archbishop, at Lambeth, for refusing to take the oath of allegiance to Queen Eli∣zabeth, and died there, Nov. 1559.
1560 James Pilkington was made Bishop soon after Tunstal's death. He died Jan. 23, 1587, and
Richard Barnes was translated hither, from Carlisle, and presided 11 years. He died August 24, 1587. The see being vacant a while
Matthew Hutton, dean of York, was raised to it; he held it 5 years, and was removed to York.
Tobias Matthew succeeded him, first in this see, and then in the archbishoprick. While he was bishop of Durham, he preached 550 ser∣mons. His successor was,
1596 William Jones. He died 1617, and
Richard Neile was translated hither from Lincoln, and within the year to Winchester, and then to York.
1627 George Mountain was only 3 months bishop of Durham, till he was translated to York, and was succeeded by
1628 John Howson, who died Feb. 6, 1631. Then was elected,
1632 Thomas Morton—He was dispossessed of his bishoprick, by the usurping powers in the grand rebellion, and died Sept. 22, 1659, aged 95.
1660 Dr John Cousins was made bishop of this see upon the restoration of Charles II. and died Jan. 15, 1674. He was succeeded by the
Hon. Nathaniel Crew, who, after the decease of his elder brothers, became a lord temporal, as well as spiritual. He was bishop 47 years, and died Sept. 18, 1721.
1721 Dr William Talbot, father of the late Lord Chancellor, was then promoted to this see. He died Oct. 10, 1730. His death made way for
1730 Edward Chandler, D. D. translated from Litchfield and Coventry. He died June 20, 1750, reported to be worth 140,000 l.
1750 Joseph Butler, L. L. D. succeeded him. He died June 16, 1757. To him succeeded the
1752 Hon. Dr. Richard Trevor, who died, 1771, when the
Hon. Dr. John Egerton, the present bishop, was translated from Litchfield and Coventry to the see.

DIV2.HEAD: MAYORS OF NEWCASTLE FROM THE FIRST.

LIST.HEAD: HENRY IV.'s ReignThe first period of sheriffs in Newcastle..

DIV2.HEAD: SHERIFFS OF THE COUNTY OF NORTHUMBERLAND, FROM 1710.
ALPHABETICAL LIST OF COMPANIES, WHEN INCORPORATED IN LONDON.
EMPERORS OF ROME.
DIV2.P: Under Jovian the Empire was divided into Eastern and Western.

DIV2.HEAD: WESTERN EMPERORS AT ROME.
DIV2.P: Desiderius was overcome by Charles the Great, of France, who succeeded him, when it was annex∣ed to the present Roman German empire.

LIST.ITEM: Alexius II. Angelus the last gr. Em. at Const. died. 1203

DIV2.HEAD: SUCCESSION OF THE BISHOPS OF ROME, FROM THE FIRST.

LIST.HEAD: Seventh Century.
LIST.ITEM: 66 Boniface III.The first who assumed the title of Pope.

LIST.HEAD: Ninth Century.
LIST.ITEM: Certain writers pre∣tend to place a fe∣male Pope, by the name of Joan; but whether there over was such an one in being or not, is left to the credulity of the reader.
Brandenburg (a marquisate), Lutherans, Calvinists, and Papists.
England (a kingdom), church of England, and all others tolerated but Papists
Genoa (a republic), Papists, and the Jews tolerated.
Greece (a part of Turkey), Mahometans, Jews, &c.
Hesse-Cassel (a landgravate), Lutherians, Calvinists, and Papists.
Netherlands, or United Provinces (a republic), Pa∣pists, Calvanists, &c. tolerated.
Prussia (a kingdom), Lutherans, Calvinists, and Pa∣pists.
Russia (an empire), Greeks, Calvinists, and Luthe∣rans.
Siberia (part of the Russian empire), Greeks and Ar∣menians.
Switzerland Cantons (a republic), six are Protestants, seven are Papists.
Tartary (an empire, partly in Europe), Armenians, Mahometans, and Greeks.
Turkey (an empire, partly in Europe), Mahometans, Jews, and Christians.
Venice (a republic), Papists, Greeks, and Jews.
ADamites, a sect of heretics, renewed, 1432
Begging Friars first established in France, 1587.
Cardinals began, 308; red hats given them, 1242; the purple given them, 1464; the title of eminence given them, 1644.
Jesuits society began, 1536; expelled France, 1764; ditto from Spain, 1767; ditto from Naples, 1768; from Rome, 1773; and from other states soon after.
Jesus, sisters of the society of, began, 1626.

DIV1.HEAD: The BIRTHS, MARRIAGES, and ISSUE of the PRINCES of EUROPE, with the Origin, and first Sovereign of each Country.

DIV2.HEAD: FRANCE.
DIV2.P: THE French Monarchy has subsisted about 1356 years, from the time that the original people left Ger∣many, and crossed the Rhine to invade the Gauls.— They have always been governed by kings, of which they reckon 66 in all, since the first establishment of their monarchy in 418. Their first king was Phara∣mond; the present king is
LOUIS-AUGUSTUS XVI. King of France and Na∣varre, born Aug. 23, 1754; married Maria-Anto∣nietta, of Austria, May 16, 1770; succeeded Lewis XV. May 10, 1774.

LIST.HEAD: Brothers and Sisters of the King.
LIST.ITEM: 1. L. Stanistaus Xavier, Count de Provence, born Nov. 17, 1755; married Maria-Josepha-Louisa, of Sardinia, May 14, 1671.
2. Charles Philip, Count d'Artois, born October 9, 1757.
3. Maria Adel. Clotilda Xaviera, born Sept. 23, 1759.
4. Eliz. Philippa Maria Helena, bo. May 3, 1764.

LIST.HEAD: Daughters of the late King now living.
LIST.ITEM: 1. Maria Adelaide, Madame of France, Duchess of Lorrain and Bar, born March 23, 1732.
2. Vict. Louisa Maria Theresa, bo. May 11, 1733.
3. Sophia Philippa Eliz. Justina, born July 27, 1734.
4. Louisa Maria, born July 15, 1737; went into a convent of Carmelites, and took the veil, 1770.

DIV2.HEAD: SPAIN.
DIV2.P: The several provinces now subject to the crown of Spain, were formerly independant kingdoms; and the Phoenicians, who were possessed of a great part of this country, were the first civilizers of this kingdom, and the founders of its most ancient cities. Atulph, king of the Goths, began to reign in 415; Ferdinand go∣verned Castile, in 1033; Ramirus governed Arragon in 1035; and in 1598, they were united by Ferdi∣nand, who first assumed the title of Catholic Majesty, and called his kingdom by the name of Spain. The present king is
CHARLES III. born Jan. 20, 1726.

P.HI: His Issue by his late Queen are

LIST.ITEM: 2. Maria Louisa, born Nov. 24, 1745; married Aug. 5, 1765, to the Archduke Leopold of Austria, great Duke of Tuscany.
3. Philip Anthony, Duke of Calabria, born June 13, 1747, declared incapable of succeeding to the throne, on account of the invincible weakness of his understanding.
4. Charles Anthony, Prince of Asturias, born Nov. 11, 1748; married to Louisa Maria Theresa, of Par∣ma, Sept. 4, 1765.
5. Ferdinand Antonio, King of the two Sicilies, born Jan 12, 1751; married the Archduchess Mary Caroline Louisa, April 7, 1768.
6. Gabriel Anthony, born May 11, 1752, Grand Prior of Spain.

DIV2.HEAD: PORTUGAL.
DIV2.P:
In 713, this kingdom, then called Lusitania, with the rest of Spain, became subject to the Moo's; and
continued so till subdued by Alphonso, in 1093, who was proclaimed their first king in 1139. The present king is
JOSEPH, born July 6, 1714; married Mar. 31, 1732, to Mary Ann Victora, Infanta of Spain, born March 31, 1718.

P.HI: The Issue of the King and Queen are

LIST.ITEM: 1. Maria Frances Isabella, Princess of Brazil, born Dec. 7, 1734; married to her uncle, Don Pedro, 1760, by whom she has issue, 1. Joseph Francis Xa∣vier, Prince of Beira, born Aug. 21, 1761; 2. John Maria Joseph Lewis, born May 1767; 3. Mariane Victoria, born Dec. 15, 1768.

DIV2.P: Don Pedro Clement, brother to the king, bo. July 5, 1717, F. R. S. married his niece, the Princess of Brazil, 1760.

DIV2.HEAD: DENMARK and NORWAY.
DIV2.P: This kingdom is of great antiquity, and had its kings long before the birth of Christ; but, as their history is very obscure, we can with no certainty men∣tion any before Gormor, in Denmark, who reigned in 714; and Suenon, in Norway, in 998. These two kingdoms were united under Eric IX. in 1412. The crown of this kingdom was elective till 1660, when it was declared hereditary, in favour of Frede∣rick III. The present king is
CHRISTIAN VII. LL. D. and F. R. S. born Jan. 29, 1746; married to Princess Caroline Matilda of England, Nov. 8, 1766; from whom he was divor∣ced, 1772.

DIV2.HEAD: SWEDEN.
DIV2.P: This kingdom is the greatest part of what was an∣ciently Scandinavia, was for some time united to the crown of Denmark, and has been a distinct kingdom only since the year 1525. It was formerly elective, till 1525, when it was made hereditary in favour of Gustavus II. The genealogy of the kings who reign∣ed in the first centuries, and indeed till the year 829, being uncertain, we shall mention Biorn for the first, who reigned in 829. The present king is
GUSTAVUS, of Holstein-Gottorp, born Jan. 1746; married Nov. 4, 1766, to the Princess-Royal of Den∣mark.

P.HI: Brothers and Sisters to the King.

DIV2.HEAD: GERMANY.
DIV2.P: This sovereignty was a kingdom, and Lewis was the first king in 143; it was erected into an empire in 800, and Charles the Great the first Emperor, first elected king of the Romans, 1056. The present Emperor is
JOSEPH BENEDICT AUGUSTUS, born March 13, 1741; crowned king of the Romans, 1764; mar∣ried Josephina Maria, of Bavaria, Jan. 23, 1765, who died in 1767; succeeded as emperor, Aug. 18, 1765.

P.HI: Brothers and Sisters of the Emperor.

LIST.ITEM: 2. Maria Christina Josepha, born May 13, 1742; married April 8, 1766, to Prince Albert of Saxony.
4. Mary Amelia Josepha, born Feb. 26, 1146; married to the reigning Duke of Parma, June 27, 1769.
5. Peter Leopold, born May 5, 1747; Grand Duke of Tuscany, Governor General of the Milanese, and Colonel of foot in the Russian service; married Feb. 16, 1764, to the Princess Maria Louisa of Spain.
6. Mary Caroline Louisa, born Aug. 13, 1752; married April 7, 1768, to the king of the two Si∣cilies.
7. Ferdinand Charles Antonine, born June 1, 1754; married to the Princess Maria Beatrice, of Modena.
8. Maia-Antonietta, born Nov. 2, 1755; mar∣ried to the king of France, 1770.
9. Maximilian Francis, born Dec. 8, 1756; elected co-adjuor to Prince Charles of Lorrain, as grand ma∣ster of the Teutonic Order, a widower.

DIV2.P: Prince Charles Alexander, of Lorrain, brother to the late and uncle to the present Emperor, born Dec. 12, 172, grand master of the Teutonic Order, a widower.
Charlotte of Lorrain, born May 17, 1714, sister to the late and aunt to the present Emperor, Abbes of Remiremont in Lorrain.
The first Duke of Lorrain was Frederick, in 958.

DIV2.HEAD: ELECTORS OF GERMANY.
DIV2.P: In 1258, nine Electors were appointed by the Gol∣den Bull to chuse an Emperor; three ecclesiastical electors, called Electoral Hghnesses; and six secular ones, stiled Most Serene Electoral Highnesses.

DIV2.HEAD: ECCLESIASTICAL ELECTORS.
DIV2.P: MENTZ. This Archbishop is the chief ecclesiasti∣cal Elector, Arch-chancellor, Prince and Elector of the holy Roman Empire, and is stiled Most Eminent, though not a cardinal. The present Archbishop is M. Emeric Joseph, Baron Breidback of Burrisheim, born Nov. 12, 1707; elected Archbishop and Elec∣tor, July 5, 1763.

TREVES. This Archbishop is second of the eccle∣siastical Electors, Arch-chancellor, Prince and Elector of the holy Roman Empire. The present Arch-bi∣shop is Prince Clement of Saxony, son of Augustus III. late king of Poland, born Sept. 28, 1739; com∣menced Archbishop, Feb. 19, 1768; also Bishop of Tresingen and Ausburg, by dispensation from the Pope.

COLOGNE. This Archbishop is the third ecclesi∣astical Elector, Grand Chancellor of Italy, Prince and Elector of the holy Roman Empire, and is one of the most powerful of the whole empire. The pre∣sent Archbishop is Maximilian Frederick, Count de Konigsegg Rothenfells, born May 13, 1708; ap∣pointed Archbishop and Elector, April 6, 1761; Bi∣shop of Munster, 1762.

DIV2.HEAD: SECULAR ELECTORS.
DIV2.P: BOHEMIA. Maria Theresa, Queen of Hungary and Bohemia, Empress-dowager of Germany, born May 13, 1717.

SAXONY. Frederick Augustus Joseph, Duke of Saxony, born Dec. 23, 1750; married, Jan. 17, 1769, to the Princess Amelia Augusta de Deux-Ponts. The Emperor Sigismund, in 1424, gave it to Frederick the Brave, Landgrave of Thuringia, and Margrave of Misnia, in whose family it has continued ever since.
BRANDENBURG. The present Elector is King of Prussia, and Marquiss of Brandenburg. This Elector has seven votes at the Diet. He is arch-cham∣berlain, and Prince of the holy Roman Empire.

PALATINE. Charles Theodore, Duke of New∣burg Sultzbach, Elector Palatine, born December 11, 1724; married July 8, 1742, to Mary Elizabeth of Sultzbach, born Jan. 17, 1721. He is Prince of the holy Roman Empire, and Protector of the order of Malta.

BAVARIA. Maximilian Joseph, Duke of Bavaria, born March 28, 1727; married July 8, 1747, to Mary Ann, of Saxony, born Aug. 29, 1728. Otto V. was made Duke of Bavaria in 1180. Grand Ma∣stership of the empire was annexed to this electorate in 1623.
HANOVER. George III. King of Great-Britain, &c. Duke of Hanover, which duchy was raised to an Electorate in 1692, Prince and Treasurer of the holy Roman Empire.

DIV2.HEAD: SAXE-GOTHA.
DIV2.P: ERNEST-LEWIS, Duke, born Jan. 30, 1745; married March 21, 1769, to Maria Charlotta, of Saxe-Meningen, by whom he has a son, Ernest, born Feb. 27, 1770.

DIV2.HEAD: MECKLENBURG.
DIV2.P: This House is divided into two branches, viz.
SCHWERIN. Frederick, bo. Nov. 9, 1717; mar∣ried, 1746, Louisa Frederica, of Wurtumberg Stut∣gard, born Feb. 3, 1722.
STRELITZ. Adolphus Frederick IV. Knight of the Garter, born May 5, 1738.

LIST.HEAD: His Brothers and Sisters are
LIST.ITEM: 1. Charles Lewis Frederick, born Oct. 10, 1741; married Sept. 18, 1768, to Frederica Charlotta Louisa, of Hesse-Darmstadt, by whom he has two daughters.
2. George Agustus, Knight of the Elephant, Go∣vernor of Zell, and LL. D. born Aug. 16, 1748.

DIV2.HEAD: POLAND.
DIV2.P:
This country has been governed by kings ever since 550, when Lechus I. ruled. This crown is elec∣tive,
and not hereditary. It is their custom not to inter their dead king till a new one is chosen. Their present king is
STANISLAUS AUGUSTUS, late Count Poniatow∣ski, F.R.S. born Jan. 17, 1732; elected King of Poland, Sep. 7, crowned Nov. 25, 1764.

DIV2.HEAD: PRUSSIA.
DIV2.P: This country was anciently inhabited by the Ve∣nedi, a powerful nation, whose kings were descend∣ed from Arthirius, the first king of the Hirul, on the Baltic, who reigned 320 years before Christ.— The Borussi, a people inhabiting the Rphaean moun∣tains, vanquished the Venedi, and possessed them∣selves of this country, which they called Borussia, now by corruption Prussia, which was reduced by the Marian Knights of the Teutonic order, sent hither by the Emperor Frederick II. in 1215. Weary of the extortions of their governors, 1219, they revolt∣ed to Jagello, King of Poland; and, in 1457, the garrison sold Marienburg, and other towns, to Casi∣mir IV. of Poland. The grand master of the Teutonic order vanquished the Poles, and kept possession till 1701, with the title of Duke of Prussia, when Fre∣derick I. put the crown on his head. The present King is
FREDERICK III. Elector of Brandenburg, Grand Master of the Teutonic order, born Jan. 24, 1712; married June 12, 1733, to Elizabeth Christiana, of Brunswick Wolfenbuttle, born Nov. 8, 1715.

DIV2.HEAD: RUSSIA.
DIV2.P:
The inhabitants of this country were not famous till 864, when they attempted to take Constantino∣ple. They were conquered by the Crim Tartars, 1240; governed by lords, tributary to the Tartars, till 1300. The refusal of the tribute occasioned wars, which terminated with their independency.
John Basilowitz was the first Czar, in 1533; Peter the Great the first Emperor, 1721. Their present sovereign is

CATHARINE II. Empress of all the Russias, Prin∣cess of Anhalt Zerbst, born March 28, 1729, ascend∣ed the throne July 9, 1762, upon the deposing of her husband, Peter III. by whom she has Paul Petro∣witz, Great Duke of Russia, born Oct. 1, 1754, who is also Duke of Holstein Gottorp, and married the eldest Princes of Hesse Darmstadt, Oct. 10, 1773.

DIV2.HEAD: SARDINIA.
DIV2.P: This country has been inhabited by divers nations; but in 1303, it was conquered by the Spaniards, to whom it belonged till 1718, when it was taken by an English fleet, and given to the Duke of Savoy, with the title of king; the first king was Victor, who abdicated the throne in favour of his son, 1730. The present is
VICTOR AME MARIA, Duke of Savoy, born June 26, 1726; married April 12, 1750, to Maria An∣tonietta of Spain, born Nov. 17, 1729. He came to the crown in 1773.

DIV2.HEAD: HOLLAND.
DIV2.P: This state was formerly subject to Spain, whose yoke they shook off in 1579, and, by the title of the Seven united Provinces, formed the republic. Each province has its own laws. William was the first Prince of Orange in 1579, and first Stadtholder.— The present is

WILLIAM V. Prince of Orange and Nassau born March 8, 1748, hereditary Stadtholder, and Knight of the Garter; married Oct. 4, 1767, to Princess Frederica Sophia Wilhelmina, of Prussia, by whom he has Frederica Louisa Wilhelmina, born Nov. 28, 1770, and another Princes, born Feb. 14, 1774.

DIV2.HEAD: SICILY and NAPLES.
DIV2.P: Roger was the first king of Naples, 1102. The present king is
FERDINAND VI. king of the Two Sicilies, third son of his Catholic Majesty, born Jan. 12, 1751; married April 7, 1768, to the Arch-duchess Mary Caroline Louisa.

DIV2.HEAD: TURKEY.
DIV2.P: Ottoman was the first Emperor at Constantinople, in 1268. The present emperor is
ABDUL HAMED, Grand Signior, born Nov. 1719; succeeded to the throne of Turkey, upon the death of his brother the late Sultan, Nov. 29, 1773.

DIV2.HEAD: HUNGARY and BOHEMIA.
DIV2.P: The government of Bohemia was founded in 550. Attilla was the first king of Hungary, 873; Warti∣slaus II. first king of Bohemia, 1086; united by Matthias in 1612. The present sovereign is
MARIA THERESA, Empress-dowager of Ger∣many, born May 13, 1717. See the article of Ger∣many.

DIV1.HEAD: OCCURRENCES, Which could not so well be ranged alphabetically.
DIV1.P: ON the fourth day of the creation, at noon, (ac∣cording to Kennedy) the earth first received its diurnal motion, bef. Xt. 4004.
Epimetheus discovered the art of making earthen ves∣sels, bef. Xt. 1715.
Weights and measures invented, and gold and silver money first coined, by Phydon, the tyrant of Ar∣gos, bef. Xt. 894.
The combat between the three Horati and three Cu∣riatii, bef. Xt. 667.
The great Circus at Rome built, which could con∣tain 150,000 persons, bef. Xt. 605.
A great many Roman ladies poisoned their husbands; 170 of them suffered death for it. This was the first example of such a crime, before Xt. 331.
The Romans quitted Britain 381 years bef. Xt.

Antiochus, son of Seleucus, fell sick, the cause of which his physician discovered to be a violent love for his father's wife, upon which Seleucus resigned his wife and a part of his kingdom to his son, bef. Xt. 204
The amphitheatre in the city of Fidana fell, and crushed 50,000 persons to death, aft. Xt. 27.
On enquiry, there was found to be 1,544,000 ci∣tizens in Rome, 48.
About this time Christmas, Easter, Ascension-day, and Penticost, were established, 68.
The Jews about Cyrene, headed by one Andrae, murdered near 200,000 Greeks and Romans.— They eat their intrails, and covered themselves with the skins of those they assassinated, 115.
The Romans destroyed 580,000 Jews, 135.
There was a total darkness at Rome at noon-day, 291.
The cross of our Saviour found upon Mount Calvery, 326.
At Rome a pillar of fire was seen in the air during 30 days, 389.
The Persian army, fearing they should be cut off by the Romans, threw themselves into the Euphrates, where upwards of 100,000 of them perished, 424.
Mount Vesuvius emitted flames in such abundance, that they were even seen at Constantinople; they obscured the sun at noon-day; and the fire ravaged and burnt all Campania, 472.
Thirty-five thousand persons massacred at Constanti∣nople, 532.
Three hundred thousand inhabitants of Milan slain by the Goths, 539.
The first canonization made by the papal authority; that of St. Uldariens, 993.

Basilius, emperor of the East, defeated the Bulgarians; made 15,000 of them prisoners, whose eyes he caused to be put out, except one man in an hun∣dred, to whom he left one eye, to serve as leaders to the rest, July 27, 1614.
Leo IX. the first Pope that kept an army, 1054.
The first English nobleman beheaded, 1074.

On the 5th of October, there fell a violent storm in several parts of England, especially at Winchels∣comb, in Gloucestershire, where the steeple of the church was thrown down by thunder and lighten∣ing, and the crucifix, with the image of the Virgin, were broken in pieces, 1091.
During the above there was also a thick smoak which darkened the sky.

On the seventeenth of the same month, there happened a storm of wind at S. W. (the same that blew in The last tempest, so dreadful to the whole nation).
In London it threw down 500 houses, and un∣roofed Bow-Church. At Old-Sarum the steeple and many houses were blown down.
The sea over-flowed 4000 acres of Earl Goodwin's in Kent, since called the Goodwin-sands, 1100.

The water of the river Medway failed so much, that the smallest boat could not float in the channel; also, the Thames was so low between the Tower and the bridge, that women and children waded over it; owing to so great an ebb in the ocean, that laid the sands bare several miles from the shore, and continued a whole day, 1113.
One hundred and fifty nobles, and the king's son, lost at sea, in coming from Normandy, 1120.

On the second of August, just as King Henry was about to take ship and sail for Normandy, there was a most terrible earthquake, during which, flames of fire burst out of certain rifts of the earth, with great violence, 1134.

Thirty German heretics came to England, to propa∣gate their opinions. They said they were Chris∣tians, but denied baptism, the Lord's supper, and matrimony; for which they were condemned by a council of bishops, at Oxford, and delivered over to the secular arm. Accordingly they were marked on the forehead with a red-hot iron, whipped, and thrust out of doors naked, in the midst of winter, where, none daring to relieve them (an order hav∣ing been published to the contrary) they died of hunger and cold, 1160.

At Christmas, at a place called Oxen-hall, near Darlington in the bishoprick of Durham, the earth raised itself up like a lofty tower, and remained several hours in that posture; on a sudden it sunk down again, with a horrid noise, and the earth so sucked it in, that it made there a deep pit, which
continues to this day. Mr Cambden supposes it to be the wells that are now called Hell-kettles, 1172.

Richard I. having obtained a victory over the French, at Gytors, "not we (says he) but Dieu et mon droit;" i. e. God and our right have obtained this victory; ever since the kings of England have made it their motto, 1193.
London Bridge took fire at both ends, and the peo∣ple, thronging to suppress it, were hemmed in, and leaping over into boats and barges, several sunk, and 3000 persons were drowned, 1214.
Wheat sold for twelve-pence a quarter, beans and oats, for four-pence, 1216.

Two impostors were crucified, for giving our, that they were both of them the Messiah, or Christ; and two women were executed, the one for pre∣tending to be the Virgin Mary, and the other Mary Magdalen, 1221.

The chimney of the chamber where the queen and her children lay was blown down by a terrible storm, and her whole appartment at Windsor was shaken and torn. Oaks in the park were rent asunder, and torn up by the roots; the whole was accompanied with such thunder and lightning as had not been known in the memory of man, 1251.

The two companies of goldsmiths and taylors of Lon∣don fought, and several were killed on both sides. The sheriffs appeased the tumult, and 13 of the most mutinous of them were hanged, as were 30 citi∣zens of Norwich, for quarrelling and fighting with the monks of that city, 1262.
Edward I.'s brother-in-law killed a chief justice in Westminster-hall, 1267.
Wheat sold in some places for twelve-pence a quarter, and not many years after for twenty shillings per bushel, as much as 6l. now, 1286.
October 14, Baliol, king of Scotland, appeared in Westminster-hall, in person, by summons, to an∣swer a complaint against him of the Earl of Fife, where he pleaded his own cause, 1293.

The establishment of the jubilee among the Christians, instituted by Pope Boniface VIII. at the end of every century; it was afterwards every 50 years, then every 25 years, at which period it is now fix∣ed, 1300.

The rains were so violent, that the harvest did not begin till Michaelmas; at Christmas, a westerly wind overthrew several houses and public edifices, tore trees up by the roots, and did a vast deal of mischief, 1330.

It rained almost continually, from the beginning of October to the beginning of December, and then came a frost upon it, which lasted 12 weeks; yet, though the corn was destroyed by it in a great measure, the war with Scotland made money so scarce, that all sorts of grain were sold at a rea∣sonable rate, 1338.
Parliamentary grants to the king were in kind: this year 30,000 sacks of wool were in the grant, 1340.

At the battle of Crescy, Edward, the black Prince, first adopted, in memory of this victory, the Bo∣hemian crest and motto, viz. three ostrich feathers, and Ich dien; i. e. I serve; the king of Bohemia being slain in the action. Succeeding Princes of Wales have continued it ever since, 1346.

It rained from midsummer to Christmas, so that there was not one day or night dry together; the wet season caused great floods and pestilence, which raged a whole year. The earth was at the same time bar∣ren, and even the sea did not produce such a number of fish as formerly. The mortality was so great, that, in the city of London, 200 bodies were bu∣ried
daily in the Charter-house-yard, notwithstand∣ing those interred in other burial places. This con∣tinued from Candlemas to Easter, 1348.

Corn and other provisions were so scarce in England and France, occasioned by a great drought, as to be remarkable for being called the dear summer. Rye was brought out of Zealand to support the poor, who otherwise must have famished for want, 1353.
Edward the Black Prince made his triumphal entry into London, 1357.

When King Edward was on his march, within two leagues off Chartres, there happened a most dread∣ful hurricane of piercing wind, that swelled a tem∣pest of rain, lightning, and hail-stones, so prodi∣giously, as to kill instantly 6000 of his horses, and 1000 of his best troops, 1359.
The law pleadings changed from French to English, as a favour from Edward III. to his people, 1362.
On the 8th of April died at the Savoy, John, king of France, 1364.
On the 22d of Feb. died at London, David, king of Scotland, 1371.
The best wine sold at 20 shillings per ton, and the second sort for 13 shillings and four-pence, 1386.
A hurricane threw down many houses, destroyed cat∣tle, and rooted up trees. This preceded a great mortality amongst youth, and after that a famine, 1389.
A dolphin was taken near London bridge 10 feet long, 1392.
John Norman, Lord Mayor of London, was the first that went to be sworn at Westminster-hall by wa∣ter, 1453.
There was taken at Erith, within twelve miles of London, four wonderful fish, viz. two whales, one sword-fish, and another called Mors Morina.

The people had an extravagant way of adorning their feet. They wore the beaks or pikes of their shoes so long, that they incumbered themselves in walk∣ing, and were forced to tie them up to their knees; the fine gentlemen did theirs with chains of silver, or silver gilt, and others with laces. This ridi∣culous custom was in vogue ever since the year 1382, but now it was prohibited, on the forfeiture of twenty shillings, and the pain of being cursed by the clergy, 1467.

The king concluded a league with the king of Castile and Arragon, by which he allowed certain Cats∣wold sheep to be transported into Spain, where the breed so increased, that their fine wool has since proved very detrimental to England, 1467.
The title of the most Christian King given to Louis XI. of France, which has continued ever since, 1469.
John Percival was drank to by the Lord Mayor, for sheriff; the first time this method of election was used, 1486.
Wheat sold in London for 4 s. a quarter, claret for 30 s. a hogshead, 1493.
No kitchen gardens in England; vegetables were im∣ported from the Netherlands. Before this time sugar was eaten with meat, to correct its put rescen∣cy, 1509.

Read, an alderman of the city of London, was im∣pressed, and sent for a common soldier, for refusing to pay an arbitrary benevolence, assessed on the city by Henry VIII. Men were never pressed at that time, unless obnoxious to law, 1544.
There were found on enquiry, to be only 58 Scotch∣men in London, 1567.
The power of granting licenses to public houses first vested in Sir Giles Momphesson and Sir Francis Mi∣chel, for their own emolument, 1621.
London was almost entirely built of wood, and, in every respect, a very ugly city. The Earl of A∣rundel first introduced the practice of brick-build∣ings, 1600.
Mount Vesuvius emitted flames in such abundance, that 4000 persons lost their lives, and a large tract of land was destroyed, 1631.
Pope Urban VIII. began to reign, who first gave the Cardinals the title of eminence, 1644.
An act passed, to make incest and adultery capital for the first offence, and fornication capital for the se∣cond, May 14, 1650.
An act passed, for solemnizing marriages by justices of the peace, Aug. 16, 1653.
Don Pantalcon desa, brother to the Portuguese am∣bassador, beheaded, for shooting Mr. Greenaway, July 11, 1654.
The day Oliver Cromwell died, there arose a storm so violent and dreadful, that it extended all over Europe, and seemed to threaten a wreck of nature, Sept. 3, 1658.
Ten of the Regicides were tried, and executed soon after, Oct. 10, 1660.
The carcases of Oliver Cromwell, Ireton, and Brad∣shaw, hanged at Tyburn, buried under the gal∣lows, and their heads set on Westminster-hall, Jan. 1, 1661.

At the public entry of the Swedish ambassador, there happened a rencounter between the French and Spanish ambassadors, for precedency, when many of their retinue were killed, on Tower-hill, but the Spanish ambassador's coach got first, Sept. 3, 1661.
A treasonable conspiracy in Ireland, discovered, June 1, 1663.
One hundred and thirty sail of Dutch merchantmen taken by the Duke of York, 1663.
The Dutch fleet sailed up as far as Chatham, and de∣stroyed great part of the English fleet, June 11, 1667.
The test act passed against the Papists; upon which the Duke of York resigned his place of admiral, Mar. 29, 1673.
A strange darkness at noon-day, so that one could not see to read, 1679.
A bill brought into parliament, to exclude James, Duke of York, from succeeding to the throne of England, 1680.
Mass ordered to be said on board the fleet, which occasioned a tumult, and the priests narrowly es∣caped being thrown overboard, 1688.
Twelve thousand Irish Catholics transported them∣selves into France, 1690.
The succession settled on the house of Hanover, 1700.
The act passed, by which the quakers affirmation is accepted in the room of an oath, Feb. 22, 1702.
The Queen ordered the words, SEMPER EADEM, to be used in her arms, as a motto, Dec. 14, 1702.

There happened such a dreadful tempest, as fright∣ened the whole kingdom. The houses in Lon∣don shook, and many fell: the water rose to a great height in Westminster hall, and London-bridge was choaked up with wreck. Thirteen ships of war were lost, and 1500 seamen. The damage at London was computed at a million sterling, Nov. 26, 27; 1703.
Two folders were whipped almost to death, and turned out of the service, for wearing boughs in their hats on the 29th of May, 1716.
A fire happened in a barn at Burwell in Cambridge∣shire, when 150 persons lost their lives, and were buried in one vault in the church, 1724.
The first person condemned to die for forgery, June 14, 1731.

Richard Smith, a bookbinder, prisoner in the King's Bench, persuaded his wife to follow his example, and make away with herself, after they had mur∣dered their infant; they were found hanging in their chamber, and their infant dead in the cradle.— They left a paper, intimating, they did it to avoid the distresses of life, April, 1732.
The Lord Mayor, one Alderman, two Judges, the greatest part of the jury, and a number of specta∣tors, caught the jail distemper, at the session-house in the Old-Bailey, of which they died, May, 1750.
Admiral Anson returned with the rich Acapulco ship, June 14, 1744.
One hundred and twenty-three persons perished in the Black-hole, at Culcutta, 1755.
The Sardinian Romish chapel burnt by accident, Nov. 30, 1759.
Dr. Solander, and Mr. Banks, returned from a voy∣age to the South-Seas, in search of discoveries, Aug. 1771.
The flowing of Solway-moss began in Cumberland, Dec. 1771.
Trade had near received a capital blow, by the failure of several capital houses, June, 1772.

Glass was invented in England, by Benedict Biscop, a monk, 664. (Benedict, says the venerable Bede, had the new abbey of Weirmouth built of stone, by French masons, after the Roman manner; he also brought over artificers skilled in the art of making glass, which, till then, had been unknown in Britain, wherewith he glazed the windows of that church and monastery, and thereby taught the Eng∣lish the art of glass-making, which has proved so useful in making lamps for churches, and other vessels for divers uses.) Glass windows began to
be used in private houses in England, 1180; glass was first made into bottles and vessels, 1457; the first glass-plates, for looking-glasses and coach-win∣dows, made at Lambeth, by the encouragement of the Duke of Buckingham, who introduced (from Venice) the manufacturing of fine glass into Eng∣land, 1674.

Sometime in the reign of Queen Elizabeth came over to England, from Lorrain, the Henzels, Tyzacks, and Tytorys. The reason of their coming hither was the persecution of the Protestants in their own country, of whose persuasion they were. They were by occupation Glass-makers. At their first coming to this town they wrought in their trade at the Close-gate, after that they removed into Staf∣fordshire, from whence they removed again, and settled upon the river side, at the place called, from their abiding in it, the Glass-houses. Deservedly, therefore, have so many of these families been named Peregrines from the Latin word peregrinus which signifies a pilgrim, or a stranger.

Having at last settled here they became very nume∣rous, and generally married into each others fami∣lies to preserve the three names of Henzel, Tyzack, and Tytory. But the latter of them within these few years became extinct. There are of the Ty∣zacks several remaining; but the Henzels are more numerous.
Tallow-candles were thought so great a luxury in England, that splinters of wood were used for light: they had no idea of wax ones, 1300.
Sedan-chairs were first used in London; a man called Duncombe, was granted a fourteen-years patent for selling them, 1634.
The art of gilding with leaf-gold, on bole-ammoniac, was invented by one Margaritone, 1273.
The art of engraving and etching, was invented by a goldsmith, at Florence; and consequently the rolling-press printing, 1460.
Engraving on wood was invented by Alb. Durer, 1521.
The emperor Charles V. was the first who had any thing that might be called a watch, though some call it a small table clock, 1530; spring pocket ones was invented by Hooke, 1658.
The first clock-makers that were in England, were three from Delft, 1368.
The first bankers were goldsmiths, whose business was to buy and sell plate, and foreign coins; and at first paid four-pence per cent. per diem, but lent to others at higher interest, 1645.

Gardening introduced into England, from the Ne∣therlands, 1509; musk-melons, and apricots cul∣tivated in England; the pale goose-berry, with salads, garden roots, cabbages, &c. brought from Flanders, and hops from Artois, 1520; damask-rose brought here by Dr. Linaere, physician to Henry VIII. Pippins brought into England by Leonard Mascal, of Plumstead in Sussex, 1525; Currants, or Corinthian grapes first planted in England, 1533, brought from the isle of Zant, belonging to Venice; the musk rose, and several sorts of plumbs from Italy, by Lord Cromwell; ta∣merisk plant, from Germany, by Archbishop Grindal; at and about Norwich the Flemmings first planted flowers unknown in England, as gilly-flowers, carnations, province rose, &c. 1567; woad origi∣nally from Thoulouse in France; tulip roots first brought into England, from Vienna, 1578; aspa∣ragus, artichoaks, oranges, and lemons, introduced into England about this time; cauliflowers somewhat later; also beans, peas, and salads, now in com∣mon use, 1660.
Sugar is first mentioned by Paul Enginetta, a physici∣an, 625; originally from China, and the east; produced in Sicily, 1148; sugar refined first in England, 1659; abroad earlier.

Painting was introduced into Rome, from the east, by Fabius Pictor, 291 years before Xt. in oil co∣lours, invented by Bruges, 1340; introduced into Venice, by Venetiano, 1450; into Italy, by An∣tonello, 1476.

A statute was made, enacting, that a runagate servant, or any, who live idly three days, be brought be∣fore two justices of the peace, and marked V, with a hot iron, on the breast, and adjudged the slave of him who brought him for two years; he shall take the said slave, and give him bread, water, or small-drink, and refuse-meat, and cause him to work, by beating, chaining, or otherwise; and if, within that space, he absent himself 14 days, to be marked on the forehead or cheek, by a hot iron, with an S, and be his master's slave for ever; second deser∣tion felony, when it is lawful to put a ring of iron round his neck, arm, or leg; a beggar's child may be put apprentice, and, on running away, a slave to his master, 1547.
The inhabitants of London, Westminster, &c. were commanded, by proclamation, to keep all their urine throughout the year, for making of salt-petre, 1626.
A law was enacted, that no capper or hatter should sell any hat above 1s. 8d. nor cap above 2 s. 8 d. 1489.

There was likewise enacted, that every person, above seven years of age, should wear on Sundays and holidays a cap of wool, knit-made, thicked, and dressed in England, by some of the trade of cappers, under the forfeiture of three-farthings for every day neglected; except maids, ladies, and gentlewomen
and every lord, knight, and gentleman of 20 marks of land, and their heirs, and such as have borne an office of worship in any city, town, or place, and the wardens of the London companies, 1571.

Time measurer by water introduced by Scip. Nasica, 159. King Alfred's time-keeper was six large wax-tapers, each 12 inches long, and divided into inches; as they burnt unequally, owing to the wind, he invented a lanthorn, made of wood, and then scraped plates of ox horns, glass being then a rarity, 887.—The ancients had three sorts of time measurers, viz. hour-glasses, sun-dials, and a vessel full of water, with a hole in its bottom.
Nero, having a foolish fancy to see a mock-burning of Troy, set Rome on fire, and lays the fault upon the Christians. This was the occasion of the first persecution, which was a dreadful one, 65.

Constantine, who was in Britain at his father's death hastening to Rome against Maxentius the Usurper, as he passed over the Alps, near the town of Au∣tun, there appeared to him a shining cross in the air, with these words, IN HOC SIGNO VINCES, which not at first understanding, he was after ad∣monished in a vision to use the cross as a military sign; which he did, and at his arrival at Rome, defeated Maxentius and his mighty army. Where∣upon Constantine openly renounced Paganism, and embraced the Christian religion; and in the 312th year of our Lord, he issued out a proclamation, per∣mitting Christians the open profession of their faith, and to assemble and build temples. The church, whose brightness and purity till then had only shined in the midst of the blood and ashes of her children, assumes a new face, and from the wild desarts where she wandered before, now comes to live in towns, and finds an entertainment even in
imperial palaces. The cross was set up as the de∣fence of the Roman people, and all the empire. — And the bishops had, by the first Christian empe∣peror's bounty, both honours and riches heaped upon them.

Charles the Great, called in French Charlemaign, was one of the greatest princes that has lived since the days of Constantine; he was courageous, virtuous, and wise, a great favourer of learned men, and an industrious propagator of Christianity, having dis∣pensed the light of the Gospel in Saxony, and the other northern parts of Germany which he con∣quered. The Boii, or Bavarians, were likewise subjected by him, and the Saracens, Huns, Danes, and Normans felt the power of his sword. Being in peaceable possessions of the kingdoms of France and Germany, he was invited by the Pope into Italy, to redress the injury Desiderius, king of Lom∣bardy, had offered. Him Charles conquered, and added that kingdom to his empire; and finally, by the pope's procurement, at Rome the people saluted him emperor, to which dignity Leo III. crowned him on Christmas-day, 800.

The Turks were masters of Syria, the lesser Asia, and all Palestine, where they very much oppressing the Christians, Simeon, patriarch of Jerusalem, writes to the Pope for relief, who calls a council at Placentia, and obtains a general cruisade for war from all the nations of Christendom, for re∣covery of the Holy-land, to be decreed, 1095 — Great preparations are immediately made for the holy war, and divers princes and noblemen, among whom Godfrey of Bulloigne (duke of Loraine, or rather of Brabant) set forward with a great army, 1096.

Tamerlane, the Tartar, began to reign, 1387. He conquered Babylon, Persia, China, and India;
overcomes Bajazet, and puts him in an iron cage, 1399. The great Mogul is descended from him.

Christopher Columbus, a native of Genoa, having, partly by his own study in geography, and partly by the information of some seamen who had been driven on some far western coast, conceived an opinion, that there was a large country westward of us, yet unknown, applied himself zealously for the discovery of it; to which purpose he first de∣sired assistance of the state of Genoa, afterwards of our King Henry VII. and of Emanuel, King of Portugal; by all whom being refused, he at length obtained it of Ferdinand and Isabella, king and queen of Spain, who, in the year 1492, gave him three ships, with men and provisions; with these he set out, and happily effected his intention, dis∣covering Cuba and Hispaniola, and returned to Spain, 1493.
Afterwards Americus Vespasius being sent forth by Emanuel, king of Portugal, discovered the southern continent of America; which name he had the ho∣nour to give to all that vast country, 1497.

Mahomet, the false prophet, flies from Mecca to Me∣dina, in Arabia, in the 44th year of his age and 10th of his ministry, when he laid the foundation of the Saracen empire, and from whom the Maho∣metan princes to this day claim their descent. His followers compute their time from this aera, which in Arabic is called HEGIRA, i. e. the flight, 622.
A company of linen weavers from the Netherlands established in London, 1386.
William Groceyn introduces the study of the Greek language into England, 1491.

The Moors, hitherto a formidable enemy to the na∣tive Spaniards, are entirely subdued by Ferdinand, and become subjects to that prince on certain con∣ditions,
which are ill observed by the Spaniards, whose clergy use the inquisition in all its tortures, 1491; and in 1609, near one million of the Moors are driven from Spain to the opposite coasts of Africa, from whence they originally came.
About 1539 cannon began to be used in ships.
Galileo, of Florence, first discovers the satellities about the planet Saturn, by the telescope, then just invented in Holland, 1608.

Lombes's silk-throwing machine, containing 26,586 wheels, erected in Derby; taking up one-eighth of a mile; one water-wheel moves the rest; and in 24 hours, it works 318,504,960 yards of organ∣zine silk-thread, 1719.
The South-Sea scheme in England begun April 7, was at its height in June, and quite sunk about Sept. 29, 1719.
Several public-spirited gentlemen begin the settlement of Georgia, in North America, 1732.

The emperor of Germany, empress of Russia, and the king of Prussia, strip the king of Poland of a great part of his dominions, which they divided among themselves, in violation of the most solemn treaties, 1772.
Captain Phipps sent to explore the North Pole, but having made 81 deg. is in danger of being locked up by the ice, and his attempt to discover a passage in that quarter proves fruitless, 1773.

The English East-India company having, by conquest or treaty, acquired the extensive provinces of Ben∣gal, Orixa, and Barar, containing fifteen millions of inhabitants; great irregularities are committed by their servants abroad, upon which government interferes, and sends out judges, &c. for the better administration of justice, 1773.

The war between the Russians and Turks proves dis∣graceful to the latter, who lose the islands in the
Archipelago, and by sea are every where unsuc∣cessful, 1773.

A plague happened at Newcastle, which raged from the 7th of May, till the 31st of December, 1636; in which time 5077 persons died, viz.
From May 7 to the 14th 59
From May 14 to the 21st 55
From May 21 to the 28th 99
From May 28 to June 4 122
From June 4 to the 11th 99
From June 11 to the 18th 162
From June 18 to the 25th 133
From June 25 to July 2 172
From July 2 to the 9th 184
From July 9 to the 16th 212
From July 16 to July 23 270
From July 23 to July 30 366
From July 30 to August 7 377
From August 7 to the 14th 422
From August 14 to the 21st 346
From Aug. 21 the the 28th 246
From August 28 to Sept. 4 520
From Sept. 4 to the 11th 325
From Sept. 11 to the 31st of Dec. when the plague ceased. 908
Total 5077

In 1669 a trial came on at the Exchequer Bar, by an order of his majesty Charles II. between the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, and the dean and chapter of Durham, on the latter attempting to build a ballast-key at Jarrow-Slake, without the li∣cense of the mayor and burgesses; and, after six hours evidence, a verdict was returned, by a Buck∣ingham jury, for the mayor and burgesses.

A beautiful statue of king James on horseback, erected upon a white marble basis, before the Exchange on the middle of the Sand hill, was demolished by the mob, who dragged the statue and its horse upon the key, and turned them over the same into the river, 1688.
Act for the better admeasurement of keels and keel-boats in the port of Newcastle, received the royal assent, Apr. 2, 1695.
Act for the better supplying the town of Newcastle with fresh water, July 5, 1698.

A party of rebels got together at Alnwick, in Nor∣thumberland; whereupon some troops of dragoons and companies of foot marched immediately to se∣cure Newcastle, where the remembrance of the hardships imposed upon that place by the Scots during the rebellion against King Charles I. armed the inhabitants against every inclination of admit∣ting their northern neighbours, and their guests, newly come out of Scotland. But afterwards, when these dangers were over, upon the arrival of some Swiss dragoons, who seeing the prosperity and riches of the inhabitants, had entertained strong resolutions to plunder the town, were ge∣nerously prevented by the English soldiers quar∣tered there, October, 1715.

In the beginning of Feb. 1735, was sound in the sand by the river Tyne, at Corbridge, a most cu∣rious and valuable piece of antiquity in Basso Re∣lievo in silver, weighing 148 oz. supposed to have been made use of by the Romans in some of their sacrifices to some heathen Deity, and to have been made above two thousand years ago. It represents the figures of Vesta, Apollo, Ceres, Minerva, and Diana, with their proper hieroglyphics, &c. This valuable piece was sold a little time after it was found, to Mr. Isaac Cookson, goldsmith in New∣castle,
who, for the sake of the connoisseurs in anti∣quity, freely gave them all an opportunity of seeing it at any time they pleased. This occasioning the affair to be divulged in all places, it came at last to the ears of the Duke of Somerset, lord of the manor of Corbridge, who demanded of Mr. Cookson the same, as his right. Mr. Cookson, being desired by his friends to acquiesce, and leave the whole to his grace's pleasure, his grace ordered Mr. Cookson to be paid back the money it cost, and over and a∣bove a present of money, 1758. This piece is now in the possession of his grace the Duke of Northum∣berland, who married the grand-daughter and heiress of the said Duke of Somerset.

A Copper medal, about four inches diameter, inclosed in a case of thick glass, was laid in the S. E. corner of a pier in the stone bridge over the river Tyne, being the spot where the boundaries of the corpo∣ration extend southwards, by Cha. Atkinson, Esq mayor, July 8, 1776.
Mr John Walker, of Newcastle upon Tyne, obtain∣ed his majesty's patent for the invention of his elastic saddles, which, on repeated trials, were found to be of great utility, 1776.
St. John's Lodge of Free-masons, in Newcastle, dedi∣cated with great ceremony, Oct. 16, 1777.

DIV2.HEAD: The Prices of Provisions at different Periods were as follow:
DIV2.P:
A fat ox 1s. sheep four-pence, provender for 20 horses four-pence, bread for 100 men 1s. 1177; wheat 1s. the quarter, beans and oats 4d. 1216; a goose 4d. a lamb at Christmas 6d. all the other part of the year 4d. two pullets three-farthings, 1299; a fat ox 1l. 4s. sheep 1s. 2d. a hog 3s. 4d. 2 chickens 1d. 4 pigeons 1d. 24 eggs 1d. wheat, beans, ae
peas, 1l. the quarter, 1314; wheat 30s. the quar∣ter, 1315; wine 20s. per tun, 1316; barley 1s. per quarter, 1387; wheat 1s. the quarter, malt 1s. 4d. 1454; wheat 3s. the bushel, 1486; wheat 1s. 8d. the bushel, 1491; wheat 4s. the bushel, claret 30s. per hogshead, 1495; a barrel of beer, with the cask, 6d. and 4 great loaves for 1d. 1553; wheat 14s. the quarter, 1558; flour 10s. the bu∣shel, 1596.
It was enacted that no victualler should sell less than one full ale quart of the best beer or ale for 1d. and two quarts of the smaller sort for 1d. 1603.

LIST.ITEM: Living was 7 times cheaper than now, 1066.
— 3 and a half cheaper than now, 1498
— near 5 times as cheap as now, 1560.

DIV2.HEAD: Elections for NEWCASTLE.
DIV2.P: 1734 Walter Blackett,Successful candidates. Nicholas Fenwick,Successful candidates. and Wm. Carr, Esqrs.
1741 Walter BlackettSuccessful candidates., Nicholas FenwickSuccessful candidates., Wm. Carr, and Matt. Ridley, Esqrs.
1747 Walter Blackett, and Matthew Ridley, Esqrs.
1754 Sir Walter Blackett, Bart. and Matt. Ridley, Esq
1761 The same
1768 The same
1774 Sir Walter BlackettSuccessful candidates., and Sir Matthew White Ridley, Barts.Successful candidates. Hon. Const. John Phipps, and Thomas Delaval, Esq
1777 Sir John Trevelyan, Bart.Successful candidates. and Andr. Robinson Bowes, Esq
PHILIP, Bishop of Durham, in the reign of Hen∣ry II. granted to the burgesses of Gateshead, se∣veral Privileges, as appears by what follows:
Philip, by the grace of God Bishop of Durham, to all men of the whole bishoprick, and of his brother∣hood in all England, he saluteth:

Know ye, that we have granted, and by this present deed have granted to our burgesses of Gatesheved, full liberty of forestage, yielding in every half year, from Pentecost to the feast of St Martin; for a wheye or ox, the which goes to grass, 2d. and for a horse, 2d. and for every hog, 1d. in respect to all things that they have to pro∣per and necessary uses; saving these prohibited. Neither shall it be lawful for any forester within the meats that are appointed within our forrest and burrough to tax lands upon any burgess, or upon any manner of thing of the said burrough, or upon any oxen, or any other their cattle, or by any ways to hinder them, either of their wood, tim∣ber, or any other things. And if any suit or trouble shall be between the forresters and burges∣ses, it shall be determined in the said burrough, if it may be; if not, then in our presence it shall be determined. And the cattle of any burgess shall not be carried out of the said burrough, but there shall be replevied, if the same may be replevied. To the same burgesses it shall be lawful to have herbage, and lying turfs and bruery to their own proper uses, wheresoever they are accustomed to have the same, so that they fell us part thereof. And if any burgess do dig turfs for his chimney, not having oxen, if for the leading of turfs they shall be forced to have oxen, nevertheless in giv∣ing for all or every ox, which they shall need 2d. of forestage, they shall be freed. And it shall be lawful for every burgess to give wood to whom∣soever
he will, to be spent about the river of Tyne, without any licence; but not to sell any without licence of the forresters. And no forrester shall disturb any merchandize that cometh within the said meat. And every burgess of Gatesheved shall have of his burgage the same liberty, which the burgesses of Newcastle have of their burgages. And whithersoever the burgesses of Gatesheved, or ther cattle, shall come within our land, in the peace of God and blessed St. Cuthbert, they shall pass, that no man to them shall do any injury, or any demand or exaction of them shall require. We do grant also to the same burgesses, that they shall have common of pasture and like parts of feeding to all their horses, and all commodities which they ought to have of Subtwell Meadows, as they were wont to have; as in deeds of good memory of our predecessors reasonably is contained.
